Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating a Novel Approach for Biological Named Entity Recognition in Text Mining
Award.AbstractNarration:
Currently, using computational resources to extract information from biological literature faces many challenges due to the domain specific terminology of biological texts. In order to read and obtain information from the vast amount of available biological literature, a large amount of funds, time and manpower are required. The amount of research literature and data is always increasing, and a scalable solution to gleaning information from biological text is necessary. This project aims to develop a new technique for extracting specific annotations from biological literature. For this project, the PI will travel to Academia Sinica in Taipei, Taiwan to work with Dr. WenLian Hsu, whose expertise in the areas of natural language processing and text mining of biological literature is necessary for the implementation of this approach.

DNA methylation is regarded as a potential biomarker in the diagnosis and treatment of cancer. Recent studies have identified relationships between aberrant gene methylation and cancer development. In previous approaches of mining biological literature, a combination of manual curation and machine learning-based approaches have been used to extract gene methylation cancer relations. This project will utilize a novel statistical pattern based approach which focuses on identifying deep and important linguistic patterns described for disease terms and physical interactions. This approach has a unique flexible matching mechanism that captures existing disease terms or protein names within the text, regardless of their previous presence in the training data. This project provides a solution to the resource limitation of reading and analyzing large amounts of biological literature in a short amount of time.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Text mining is the process of deriving high quality information from text. Although this has been an area of research and development for many years, the mining of biological literature continues to face unprecedented challenges due to the variety of highly specialized biomedical domains. In biological areas of research there is a wide array of complicated terminology and nomenclature that is difficult to train computers to interpret. Another major problem in text mining lies with ambiguous sentences in text which humans are easily able to decipher but are difficult for computational programs to effectively interpret.

When computational programs are created to extract information from text they must first be trained with a training data set that will teach the model common patterns within the text and how it should interpret them. However, models usually fall short because there is no way to train a model on every possible combination of words, and so there are always mistakes or data that is unable to be extracted. This is where a novel method known as the statistical pattern based approach (SPBA) promises improved results. The statistical pattern based model has flexible pattern matching which allows for insertions and deletions within the sentences. This means that the algorithm is able to correctly understand and interpret sentences that were previously difficult for algorithms to understand. The unique approach allows for the algorithm to recognize different linguistic patterns and sentences from those that it was trained with, and still be able to extract information from the text. However, such effective performance comes with the cost of a large amount of necessary training data which must be manually annotated by an expert in the biomedical domain.

For this NSF-EAPSI project, I traveled to the Intelligent Agent Systems Lab at Academia Sinica in Taiwan where the statistical pattern based approach was created. The goal was to understand this novel technique and learn if it could be incorporated into a system that suggests key-value pairs from biological text to users. I completed the annotation of a novel data set for training with the statistical pattern based approach and wrote a sequence of scripts that allow for an improved process of data annotation utilizing the benefits of both computational and manual resources. Such solutions that utilize the speed of computers and the accuracy of human validation optimize on the strengths of each method and save researcher’s time. During my time in Taiwan, I learned how the statistical pattern based model works and how to best solve the problem of suggesting key-value pairs to a manual annotation system.

Moving the advances of biological text mining one step further promises improvements to all domains of biological research. Decreasing the amount of time that researchers have to spend reading papers will create more time for creative tasks that will move science forward at a faster pace. In addition, international collaboration is a necessary step towards creating improved solutions to the issues facing biological text mining. By strengthening the relationship between universities in Taiwan and the United States, the pace of research discovery in this realm of work will only continue to increase.
